reasons_for_stage_number:
We still have a long way to go and we are just at the beginning stages of becoming a user-centered organization.  Many people are skeptical of the value of ux research and they don't understand or don't want to understand the importance of how a person feels when he or she is interacting with one of our products, services, or spaces.  This could be partially be my fault. 

Maybe I haven't done a good enough job of changing this way of thinking.  Also, for some, quantitative data is all that matters ( I do employ mixed-use methods most of the time).

As the ux librarian, I am on my own and have to enlist help when needed (which is not easy to do).  I think we need a team of people dedicated to ux.
UX is part of a few position descriptions, but there is no one officially in charge of UX and no budget line although funds have been allocated (very small amount) to buy treats.

Most UX activities are initiated by a single manager and around a limited set of web services. There is a dedicated usability testing group. All other activities - from research, design, prototyping, and other benchmark testing are at this stage largely ad hoc.
I was at a Stage 5 organization, and now I'm back in a Stage 3 organization, but with the UX title. I don't have a budget or staff, but I'm at least recognized as the UX coordinator!

They hired me as a UX Librarian but had no idea what UX was and no intention of improving the UX (there's a long story behind that). I faced nothing but hostility towards UX and my work throughout my entire tenure.
This is the best match for UX at my institution. But really it's more individual led (by me) and others at least realize/aspire that we should design for users and gauge their needs.

I am the UX Designer here for the library. It is my job to think from a user's viewpoint and design accordingly. I also chair a Web Working Group which focuses on improving our website from a usability standpoint.

My organization does have a budget dedicated for UX, a user experience group, and a usability working group. However, there does not seem to be a coordinated charter for integrated user experience and user-driven design across library services - there is a disconnected set of small-group efforts that are only loosely connected by virtue of existing within the library.

We're between 3 and 4. It's kind of tricky, because we had a staff member dedicated to UX who attempted to initiate a UX group. Since their departure, we've dropped back to 3. However, we're reorganizing and will have a UX department in the coming year.

Large portion of library faculty and staff understand the need for ongoing UX efforts, and many of them have volunteered to help with UX work.



Library administration, on the other hand, does not understand the need or value of UX work. The libraries' usability group was officially disbanded this past year.

UX work is often completed as a collaboration between Library Assessment and Library IT, two separate departments within two separate divisions.  The personnel costs associated with planning and performing UX work come out of both budgets, but the material costs (iPads, incentives, etc.) are budgeted as Library Assessment anticipated costs.

100% Skunkworks. I'm a self-taught designer/developer and "just fixed it" (the library website) one day. Now it's my main job duty even though it's not in my title, my job description (definitely not my salary range), and I don't have any type budget let alone the dev tools I need to do this kind of work. The library itself has recognized how important this is, and we have an ad-hoc task force that tackles these issues, but the college is not involved.

We don't fit cleanly into any of the stages, but stage 5 is the closest because we have a dedicated UX Analyst, but UX work is not yet integrated into our general project planning, strategic planning, or development processes. Some departments make good use of this person than others, but the technical department that is dedicated to application development (rather than supporting the library's core systems) does not have any UX integration yet.

Library administration believes in the value of UX but incorporates UX into job responsibilities. However, after I leave following my 2 year temp position (ends in July 2018) in usability and assessment, there is no centralized support.

Stage 6 is true for most of our web and application development, but we have a dedicated UX group who focuses on that. I would say in the rest of the organization is closer to stage 3. UX is valued, but most project teams try to bring UX or design thinking into their work the best they can.

I think we are still floundering between "Dedicated UX Budget" and "Managed Usability" ... UX is a team effort and although we have dedicated library staff, it takes everyone to make recommendations reality. We have the UX experience, but we often don't have the technical experience to implement changes that would make systems, spaces, and programs more user friendly so it becomes part of a larger library-wide effort. We are at the stage where people know they should consult with us, but either they don't OR they do but don't really hear the results, they are using us to confirm what they want to hear. We also aren't "built in" to any major processes, when consulted it is often too late in the decision making process where major decisions have already been made and thus we can only have a minimal effect.  And all of these reasons explain why we aren't higher on the scale.

we are really in between 5 and 6 right now -- iterative design is being used in some projects, including one very high-profile one, but it's not 100% throughout the organization. I would say we are around 5.75

We have a dedicated UX team, led by a UX Librarian. The team is the same as the "Web" team so we include developers, designers, content strategy, and UX analysts. I would've chosen Stage 6 but there are quite a few silos of teams in the Library that operate independently and don't take advantage of best practices for UX. (Other independent teams tap in our department to do testing and help them improve projects, though it's generally a one-off relationship, not an ongoing process, though we're working to improve that.)
Budget is our biggest constraint when it comes to UX testing.

We have a UX department and UX is involved in many of the projects that happen in the organization. For UX owned projects the process is user-driven, however, not all projects in the very large organization include UX from the start or are set up to best utilize user data. The various sources of user data are owned across several departments and a system for sustainable analysis of that data is still being developed. 



Being at Stage 8 is within the latest strategic plan.

I selected stage 7 as my workplace has been very supportive in addressing UX issues both in digital and physical spaces. I realize that this is probably made easier/possible as our library team for both locations in [redacted] is quite small, this means that the chain of command for approval of projects and research is easier compared to a larger federal library. Since being hired, I have created workflows that incorporate data that we gather from users. If there isn't data gathered in a certain area, we usually find a way to update workflows so that we can get that data.  Almost every project that I have worked on digitally and in the physical spaces at the library has been the result of UX/UI data that has been gathered from our users.
We have a dedicated UX working group; however we have no budget or anyone who is fully dedicated to UX work.

my department [redacted] was formed to look at users experiences (thought we dont do a lot of the web side of things) we are pretty user focused with everything we do. so we are almost a stage 6 or 7 but its not like that is every department (yet!) but in mine, which is the public services areas and building.
The organization is aware of the growing trend in UX, but lacks the understanding necessary to commit to it as a organization-wide practice.
We have a UX group with a charter, and will soon be posting a position for a UX librarian.

I wish i could say we're at Stage 8, but we're not. I am the UX librarian and I lead a team of 5 (incl myself) through various UX-related projects. We have no dedicated budget, but we have support from the College Librarian and other directors. At times, decisions are still made from personal experience (and from understanding campus politics).
We have had a UX Office since December 2010. As we are start projects, it is now common to have a UX component, or consulting session. UX input is mostly always solicited.
We need a position to manage our UX work ultimately and I do believe we're headed in that direction. But we don't have a systematic approach yet.

I am the UX librarian and am involved with almost every project and committee that touches users but since we are a small institution, my time is split between UX and the rest of my duties in systems and collection management. Project life cycles, for the most part, do have at least basic user research, some sort of assessment, and usability studies included.

As a small library, we don't have the staff or budget for a dedicated U/X person or team, but we are trying to be more intentional about incorporating U/X methods whenever we design or redesign an interface.

My organization is actually between Stages 4 and 5. Stage 4 perfectly describes where we've been for about 3-5 years, but my position has recently been dedicated to both assessment and user experience as a full-time position. I have the time and the position, but have found it challenging to chip away at the prevailing culture of Stage 4.

I have recently been hired to partially work with UX and another person has been appointed UX coordinator. We are just getting started talking and planning how we can move from sporadic testing to something a bit more structured.
We are in the process of hiring a UX position, although we have a pretty robust culture of assessment and have conducted multiple assessments with users, including user testing.

There are usability projects underway, there are usability aspirations, and one individual is assigned towards the effort but there aren't enough resources allocated or an integrated approach that is widely accepted.

I have the title UX Librarian and supervise a full-time staff position. I also chair a cross-departmental UX team that mainly serves in an advisory capacity.



Depending on the service or question, our Library could still fall into stage 1 with hostility/strong reluctance to implementing changes in response to usability testing, i.e., we are still staff-centered in areas. 



Overall, we've matured through the stages. In the past, I was involved in a personal research project involving usability testingâ€”now there is a dedicated position for it. 



We do employ user research to determine where to target priorities and strategy. However, I do not think we have a robust process for iterative testing or participatory design yet.

Senior library admin leadership was stable for a period of time, during which serious engagement with UX values and aims were within our sights.  However, a series of senior administrative shifts have occurred over the last decade, which as disrupted the original, positive trajectory.  No sign that we're on a true recovery course, but there are small, ad hoc efforts to from time to time.

My full-time position is user experience strategist and I manage a small UX team housed within library administration. UX has started to infuse the culture of the organization broadly, which is pretty awesome. Just last year, the UX team moved into administration so that we can tie our work to strategic planning for the organization. I'd love to say we were up to stage 6 or higher, but because it's a large organization it would be an exaggeration to say that library administration monitors UX indicators like other success indicators. Unfortunately, services and spaces are still designed (in pockets) without full attention to or tracking of the user experience. I'm trying to push us towards infusing UX outcomes into projects, but it's a long road. Within certain departments and teams in the organization, especially the web design and development teams, the maturity level is higher.

We are somewhere in Stage 5-7.  I chose 7 because that is what I am doing, but I still need to convince other librarians and administrators that UX should be done in different stages of a product development cycle.  I was able to do that with our website redesign, but for other projects I still need to educate others even my boss to put me out there at the start of a project.

Especially for website design we have been using usability testing, card sorts etc to bring in the user perspective.  However, this is essentially initiate by one individual who brings other along in the process.  

Additional colleagues have conducted interviews with faculty, or gotten some feedback from students but overall it is not systematic at an organizational level.

We have a dedicated UX librarian (me) who owns UX and usability, so stage 5 is the most accurate. I don't know if UX has become a necessarily planned activity across the whole organization. I am team of one, and though I've tried, I haven't been able to add anyone else to form an official UX team as well.



The bit in Stage 4 about the main method being user testing (and being mostly late in the dev process) is very accurate for my organization. I have pushed for more discovery/exploration and it's gained traction in some groups better than others.



So perhaps we're at Stage 4.5 or something like that.

We do have a UX librarian, and there may soon be a usability lab.  I am new at my position; the previous librarian in this position was the first, but burned out after a few years.



We do try usability work earlier and throughout our project stages, but actual development is hampered by a small dev staff/competition for resources.

Well, I think we're a bit at stage 3 and a bit at stage 5.  We have an established team doing UX work, but I use my office supply budget to pay for incentives, etc.  We hired an assessment librarian, who has willingly/enthusiastically gotten involved in the UX work--but this person did not have UX experience coming in to the position.  (I have been lobbying for a UX librarian for years.)  [redacted]

We are somewhere between Stage 6 and 7.  In some divisions within the library, user research and user data are more integrated into service design and support - when creating new services or when evaluating existing services. We have multiple teams in the library to help with service design, conducting and gathering user research, and helping library staff think more about the user in their everyday work. We also have a couple Special Interest Groups (SIGs) dedicated to user research, UX, and assessment. We have a Digital Accessibility Team that shares their expertise on digital accessibility standards and accessible design best practices, provides accessibility audits to library staff building tools or evaluating electronic resources, etc. They essentially strive to improve the virtual experiences for those with disabilities. 



We also have multiple departments within the library with UX expertise. For example, in Library IT, there is a department called [redacted] with several people dedicated to user research, design, content strategy, accessibility, and overall improving the user experience of our web applications across the web presence. They are taking a more holistic approach to a comprehensive virtual space redesign, including the libraryâ€™s website as the core, but extending more broadly to the libraryâ€™s whole suite of web-based applications and products that have a public-facing user interface. They are also refining a digital playbook and building a design system that will have unified set of principles, guidelines, and reusable patterns used in the creation of websites and web applications; this includes content, design, and accessibility guidelines as well as code for all library staff to use. 



There's another department in Operations called [redacted] that focuses on the UX of our physical spaces. They also do a lot of user research and design to help with way-finding, signage, designing spaces based on services and user needs, etc. They work very closely with [redacted]. 



Finally, in addition to all the folks in the library who do assessment/have assessment in their title, we've just hired a new Assessment Specialist in the Deans' Office to help coordinate all the assessment efforts in each of the 8 divisions, and the new Senior UX Specialist in [redacted] will be working closely with this person on UX strategy to help with future directions and library-wide assessment and planning.



If you need more info about any of this, I'm happy to talk with you all more.

I'd say we are somewhere in between 4 and 5.  There are a few staff that have UX specifically in their job description, but we are a few years in and haven't moved too far beyond usability testing as our primary UX work.  There isn't a formal budget for UX beyond staff time and a few hundred dollars for snacks and giftcard incentives.  Direction and guidance from administration has been very vague and doesn't always fit the definition of what UX work actually is.
We are almost to stage 4 - we lack a dedicated budget although I can usually get some funding for specific projects.
Our organization has a great focus on assessment, particularly in instruction, but not as much of a UX-specific focus.

I've just been hired to fill this role. We have a small committee previously established to look at UX, but until now the library hasn't had someone with certifications and enough experience to guide the group, develop practices to be used for service design, etc.

I'd say we're between stage 4 and stage 5. We have a dedicated department, but lack support from administration to really do the work we want to do. This includes 2 vacant positions in our department. I'm hopeful that we'll move forward in the next year or 2 to a fully staffed department that will allow us to work more efficiently and become more user-driven.

This is hard because I think my organization fluctuates between 4,5, & 6 - we are large and different areas of the library operate in different ways. So, for instance, I work in a small department that offers a very specialized type of service within the library. While we don't have dedicated UX staff, when we are planning and implementing new services, procedures, or workflows, we take on the role of UX staff in that planning and do testing, observation, often interviews with customers and employees, and use that information to refine these services or procedures - so a continual conceptualize, design, deploy, evaluate, refine, etc. type of cycle.
We have a couple dedicated user experience librarians
I'd say we're somewhere between 5 and 7 - it's not uniform throughout our organization. There are aspects about 5, 6, and 7 that are true in various areas of our organization.

I selected level 3 because there's a difference between what my department - the iSchool - is doing with UX, and what the University of WI as a whole is doing. We're basically skunkworks UX - doing what we can without a budget - while different departments at UW are at other levels on the scale. I think the University as a whole is probably 4

As far as I know, we donâ€™t have any dedicated usability assessment - what little information on usability we have is from developersâ€™ research or gleaned by accident from larger assessment efforts. (For example at my regional campus we have a graduation survey for the whole campus, and Iâ€™ve gotten UX information from comments on it.) Iâ€™ve also employed my own intuition on UX, changing the layout of the library to be more useful to people seeking Library staff, but I was constrained by lack of budget, etc.

We are only just beginning to think about usability in terms beyond ourselves. But we have no budget or dedicated team to study usability in any sort of systematic way. Some of us are gathering data very informally - through talking with students in other contexts and the occasional non-rigorously-designed survey.
